author: @availanila
text:
In Africa, political and commentary YouTubers are so rare! It's so bad Wode Mayo is out biggest and best political and commentary YouTuber *but he's a travel and lifestyle YouTuber* üò≠üò≠. 
So I watch Black American and Caribbean channels most but I didn't know you guys were a bit of a rarity until I started expanding my repoitre and it barely nudged before bumping into _The Shade Room_ and _Shade Room Adjaceht_ channels. You guys are a gem and invaluable.

replies.author: @wade2033
replies.text: Please don‚Äôt lump every African country into this box. South Africa has a lot of active political and commentary YouTubers, such as Penuel The Black Pen (on the Konvo channel), and SMWX (Sizwe Walsh), to name a few.

replies.author: @availanila
replies.text: @wade2033  I watch all African commentary channels. I know what's around here, channel sizes, channel's reach, and as much as possible personal politics.

replies.author: @wrestlinganime4life288
replies.text: Well Wode Maya at least showed the positive of africa

replies.author: @availanila
replies.text:
@wrestlinganime4life288  not just Africa, but countries with sizeable (or majority) black populations around the world. He also discussed inter and intra country conflicts. 
He openly discussed the split of Somalia, the colonization of the Saharawi Republic and the French Island colonies still in existence. For a fairly apolitical guy he's very political.

replies.author: @availanila
replies.text: @minti-ldn ü§∑ if you want to believe we're operating at the same level as the North American and Caribbean countries then okay.

replies.author: @elizabethajiduah2387
replies.text: @tupacmachine hey this isn't a channel but there's a website called Africa is a country! It does a pretty good job discussing the political issues on the content.

replies.author: @BooksandLooksTV
replies.text:
I think it isn‚Äôt safe for most Africans to discuss political affairs because of the backlash
Even those who moved abroad are afraid to speak up on video because they want to return to the country or want to protect their families still residing there

replies.author: @obatalaosun2222
replies.text: @BooksandLooksTV Right

replies.author: @obatalaosun2222
replies.text: ‚Äã@wade2033 South Africa is one country in one region. The rest of the continent is not represented in independent, truth telling journalism because people get jailed, tortured, the homes burned, accounts frozen, or murdered for speaking against those with money and power. That has not changed.

author: @Kaltag2278
text: Growing up, whenever I "sounded black" my (white) grandma would correct me and say I sounded unintelligent. I don't know that she will ever understand how much racism she's internalized. She was horrified when I started pointing it out and is willing to accept when she is in the wrong. I wish more people were as willing to have their deep seated beliefs challenged; even when they don't understand right away.

replies.author: @niyaakbar1098
replies.text: I‚Äôm happy she loves you enough to be horrified by her past actions AND want to change. Not many people can say that about their loved ones

author: @happygucci5094
text:
Foreign you right- this is Respectability politics and class collaboration within Black culture. And Leftist spaces without a Fanonian/ Marxist/anti-capitalist/Imperialist / womanist/black abolitionist feminist lens- then it‚Äôs not a left position at this point of later stage capitalism.

There is a lot of conservative type of gatekeeping of Blackness masquerading in Black Leftist intellectual spaces. How many working class black leftist do we see on Cornbreadtube? How many people are talking about working class issues of rent/housing crisis, redlining? Healthcare? We DO need education and engagement with political issues! We need more views that have ideological differences, political differences. That‚Äôs what the Panthers did- and we have the platforms to reach more people. 

We need commentators to teach media literacy. To teach legal issues. And we need to reach out to our elders to see how they lived  through different eras- and learn from them. We need more intergenerational conversations surrounding Black Liberation practices and politics.

author: @CamJames
text:
"News with a laugh" is kinda our only option. If you're not making people laugh (at least some of the time), you won't reach as large of an audience. Comedy is shared; same reason every SuperBowl ad maximizes their investment by throwing hella jokes at the wall until something sticks. 

I also encountered the depression of my content that FD mentioned here. One of my episodes was about Immigration, and YouTube dropped a nuclear bomb on my numbers. I literally had people unknowingly unsubscribed from my channel.

author: @1st_Amendment_Freedom
text:
Loved this  video with all of you! Each of you nailed it and called the truth. I just want to comment on this issue of trying to capture the less informative segment of the
population. Never feel you have to lose your intelligence to be able to relate to them and gain their attention! I was an ignorant ass well into my 40s and like so many others, had to look hard in the mirror when Trump entered our daily lives. I have been inspired by so many of the intellectual content creators on YouTube, it encouraged me to seek out the education I was lacking. At age 45, I enrolled in the Political Science program at UCF online and immersed myself in the world of lefties. I‚Äôm grateful to all of you for an amazing exchange of ideas, amongst a group that displays such black excellence!

author: @perhaps1094
text:
As a black person in britain ive found myself in the past viewing outlets like the shaderoom or the complex podcast (the one with budden and akademiks ü§¢)  as representative of black americans and it made me feel very weird cus the comments are so reactionary and most of the time v negative
Took me a while bf4 i realised just how shady some of these outlets are

replies.author: @handle-Generic
replies.text:
Honestly, they're in the entertainment industry. Their 1st job is to get all of us to view their content by any means.

They are not to be taken seriously or trusted as sources of credible information.

replies.author: @perhaps1094
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@handle-GenericI never understood this as a teen online and it Def brought me to some online spaces with some real grossness in them
Also I'm pretty disconnected from black American culture so it took me a while to see dudes like Joe budden for what they rlly are (vultures lol)
I love olay and everyone on the panel but I even view these guys through that same lense as well cus I know being a content creator is some real pressure that can take you too weird places.
TLDR; I learnt some critical thinking lol

replies.text: Those type outlets are sensationalist by their very nature, anyway. They're the black American online version of Daily Star, lol. I wouldn't go to them for credibility, substance or trust them as a broader representation of black America.

author: @VettieSincere
text: This was such an insightful video. I have an idea of how we got to the state of decline in black media but I‚Äôm not really sure what happened to journalism in general. Content creation is a gift because it allows you to connect with other like minded individuals and as a creator you get to educate, tell stories, have conversations etc. but sometimes the lines get faded between opinion, misinformation, and actual facts which is a whole other issue. I appreciate y‚Äôall for talking about this it‚Äôs a conversation that needs to be had by everyone in this space. I‚Äôm just getting started on this journey of content creation on YouTube so I‚Äôm just soaking everything up!

author: @Fellowluv12
text:
One aspect about audiences and "call outs"/"accountability" and their perception of "what someone should be doing" that I've been exploring recently is the idea that a lot of these people (myself included) aren't doing "the thing". 

Our interaction,  and consequently, our feeling of contribution is purely through consuming the content people put out. So when they/you show other sides, they lash out because now they feel like they aren't able to "contribute" in their normal fashion. 

Additionally, nuance *is* harder to have when you're not in the trenches of doing something. For example, how do you know what a stranger on the internet should do re accountability if you haven't tried to go through the process with someone you want to have a relationship (any type) with irl? Shits HARD 


Either way, great episode and shout out to Foreign for directing me to this page!

author: @brandonwintpoetry

author: @TheN1406
text: As an auntie that is just entering journalism, I really enjoyed this conversation. At this point in time being a journalist seems like a great idea because there is more of an opportunity to have your voice heard. However, not such a great time because we as creators have not come up with a way to monetize said voice.   Black people have always had to work outside of the established system to ‚Äúthrive‚Äù no matter the industry and then as soon as we become successful, we end up being purchased by the established system and then we kinda go back to square one. It sucks that to be a thriving black person, you have to carry sooooo much on your shoulders. And i know that we have the ability to imagine something different and better but it seems we never have the necessary means to achieve it. So, bless you all and the work that you do.

author: @hypnoamber3248
text:
@Olay this is a heads up for everyone on the panel with YouTube channels.  When yt switch to an AI algorithm program that was supposed to be more tailored to the user, all the black creators I subbed to were deleted from my favs. I had to go back and re-sub to all of my favs because the system unsuded me. 

On a Demon Mama live stream the other night we watched a video about this, I think the creator was let it cook, but I mentioned this in my comments and there were so many other wt leftist who said the same thing happened to them. This is just a heads up. 

Also conscious lee is one of the few creators that talks about disability and as a disabled person that means the world to me but there is definitely a void of disabled black creators in this space, or even people that talk about ableism. 

This was a great discussion and I learned a lot. So thankful to you and the panel.

author: @ObsidianLife
text:
Super interesting subject.  //EDIT:  To avoid confusion/misunderstanding, like me be clear-THIS is what I'm trying to say:

"Black Folks NEED real news more than anybody.  That's the overall issue."//

As I watch two things occur;

1) Black Folks DO respond to trauma with humor.  This was epitomized with Richard Pryor who was able to STILL show his anger while making people laugh.   
2) On just the human side, we should not ignore John Stewart and Fox News using humor.  Humor is a secret weapon that both Roger Ailes and Stewart understand.  Information with a dopamine spike gets across better.  This is also part of why (that a$$hole) Trump won in 2020, humor ingratiates.  

The Black Channels that lead with slang ("its ya Boy, its ya Girl") ARE trying to ingratiate themselves at the risk of not being taken seriously, while cold hard journalism is resisted.  Reminds me of Chuck D and Flavor Flav and how Chuck understood (at the time) that part of Flavors' role was to draw people in SO they would get the message as much as possible.  

Does it work?  Sometimes...I'd much rather watch FD or Olay than someone who's only got jokes, but I'm not sure  the general public WANTS that...unfortunately.  Most hardcore, accurate and QUALITY News, even amongst White Folks (Democracy Now for example) isn't exactly popular either though...

Black Folks NEED real news more than anybody.  That's the overall issue.

replies.author: @ObsidianLife

author: @bubbagiles55
text: I really appreciate the content you and your colleagues provide. These discussions are very important and I think provide context to how you all move in social media. One thing that stood out to me is that you all want black people to live on a spectrum, so I would love to see you all bring on a more conservative or liberal blacks. Not Candace Owens lol but more centrist, it doesn‚Äôt have to be a debate but just a discussion on prospectives and ideas just like this show. It may not be this platform since it‚Äôs more of a round table of like minded individuals, discussing general black ideas/issues, but I think there room for your channels to grow if you all reach out to people who don‚Äôt totally agree with you. Again thanks for the great content.

author: @1-of-1
text:
Fellow ü•∑üèæ this content is amazing and covered so many great topics. I wanna say that you Olay pulled me into your audience by being authentic. Black content can cover all topics, but when I click on your video I do it to hear your take on whatever topic. I understand that there is incentive to having a big audience and spreading the messages. At the same time when most black people come to YouTube we are looking for the opinions of the ppl we are subscribed to not so much the subject matter. So by being authentic, well read , and open-minded your audience will grow in time. You may not see the number roll in from the start but you will have a more profound impact then other creators. The best way to achieve any goals is slow and steady. 

Thank you for uploading content it is truly amazing to see and ingest.

author: @LBYRNTH_
text: The easiest emotions to elicit are anger and lust. Crazy how true that is in these social media spaces and how I don't at all doubt how difficult it is to navigate content creation with those parameters but it's also wild how I personally do not be coming to youtube to be angry or horny. I be tryna relax to videogame Let's Plays and, lately, just watching content like this where Black folks are just vibing and having fun with a healthy helping of education. What does it mean on a social level when the angries and the hornies recieve the most social capitol? What's the long game of trying to pull back from that if it's even possible?  Idk why my head is stuck on this particular part but it is what it is.

author: @progressiveGal73
text: Coming up in the 70‚Äôs, 80‚Äôs, and even the 90‚Äôs~it was worse. As a middle class black kid there was nothing that reflected back to me my own face and mind. Black forums were indeed academics and intellectuals ~but what‚Äôs going on here is smart, avg discussion ~the change happens slowly, incrementally, and it‚Äôs also the reason we should never balk at or be discouraged by incremental change. When we keep plugging away we will hit critical mass. I love watching you guys~you keep my hope alive, quite honestly üôèüèΩüíôüíö

replies.author: @progressiveGal73
replies.text: What I mean to say is your viewers haven‚Äôt come of age yet~but they are coming so please keep doing what you do~and if it‚Äôs the yt eyes paying the bills~then good, they‚Äôre keeping the seat warm for my 16 yo daughter.

author: @devonedwards4395
text:
I think the point that WASN'T discussed was the difference between "black-OWNED" media &    "black TARGETED" media.
     These gossips sites are the latter,and after almost 2 hours of conversation NO ONE brought up Black Star Network which is BLACK OWNED.
      I guess this is a conversation NOT for my age group (53) but what I see is that some of us as black people prefer to be entertained while relying on someone to tell us who/what's important.
     You can can millions who can recite cƒ•apter & verse of the Katt Williams interview & STILL believe the government gave out crack pipes.
      It's like we have a built in excuse for ignorance while also demanding excellence but when we get it we want it the way we want it.
     I think the broader conversation needs to be had but again my issue is that you didn't bring up or talk to somebody has been doing the very thing you guys say is missing.
